Lord Dormand of Easington asked Her Majesty's Government:
What has been the cost of promoting and implementing the scheme to recruit licensed teachers, and how many such teachers have been appointed.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Department of the Environment (Baroness Blatch): Under the Local Education Authority Training Grants Scheme the department allocated funds in support of expenditure of £2·36 million for the financial year 1990–91 to assist local education authorities with the cost of training licensed teachers. Bids from 69 local education authorities for the financial year 1991–92 are under consideration.
Local education authorities and governing bodies have so far appointed 327 licensed teachers.

section.title: DISCONTINUED VOLUNTARY SCHOOLS: DISPOSAL OF ENDOWMENTS

body.p: Lord Denning asked Her Majesty's Government:

Whether a diocesan authority can make an application under Section 2 of the Education Act 1973 in respect of a closed voluntary school where the premises have been sold unlawfully by the diocesan authority itself or by other unknown persons without an order under Section 29 of the Charities Act 1960 or Section 2(3) of the Education Act 1973.

Baroness Blatch: Diocesan authorities may make application under Section 2 of the Education Act 1973 in respect of the endowments of any discontinued voluntary school which can be shown to have been held or used for or in connection with the provision at the school of religious education in accordance with the tenets of the religious denomination in question. WA 38 Such applications may relate to the school site and premises or the proceeds of sale of such land and property.

Where an application relates to land and property, orders under Section 2 of the 1973 Act provide authority to sell in accordance with subsection (3). Where proceeds of sale are involved, the Secretary of State seeks to establish whether the premises were sold —
(a) by authority of the Charity Commissioners under the Charities Act 1960 or
(b) in exercise of the powers conferred by Section 14 of the School Sites Act 1841 or
(c) under the provisions of Section 1(2) of the Reverter of Sites Act 1987.
Orders made under Section 2 of the 1973 Act, therefore, invariably incorporate the proceeds of sale of premises which have been sold lawfully.
Lord Gainford asked Her Majesty's Government:

What further steps have been taken towards identifying possible locations for additional runway capacity to serve the South East, following the publication by the Civil Aviation Authority in CAP 570 of advice on the adequacy of airport capacity in the longer term.

Viscount Davidson: My right honourable friend the Secretary of State for Transport announced in July his intention to establish a working group to examine the wider implications of development at airports identified by the Civil Aviation Authority in CAP 570 as likely to be able in air traffic control terms to accommodate additional air traffic. Work has since been going forward on the group's terms of reference, structure and membership.
We have concluded that the terms of reference for the group should be:

"To evaluate the wider implications of developing additional runway capacity at the sites identified by the Civil Aviation Authority in CAP 570 as likely to be feasible for such development in air traffic control and airspace terms;

"To have regard to the considerations, including the environmental considerations, which led the Government in 1985 to the view that second runways should not be built at either Gatwick or Stansted; and to the relevance of those considerations at Heathrow and at other airports;

"To test the authority's conclusions in CAP 570 on the contribution of regional airports, and to gauge the extent to which these airports can play a part in meeting the overall demand into the next century;
"And in the light of these considerations to advise the Secretary of State on the possible courses".

We intend that the group should be chaired by a senior official from our department, and that it should be assisted by four subgroups addressing, for each of the locations identified in CAP 570, the implications for regional development and the environment; for aircraft noise; for surface access; and capital costs, lead times and other practical and technical considerations. The first of these subgroups will be chaired by the Department of the Environment, the second and third by the Department of Transport and the last by the CAA.

Invitations to join the working group or one of its subgroups have today been sent to a variety of organisations. We have asked SERPLAN to co-ordinate the local authority input, and have also sought the involvement of the Kent Economic Development Board. To represent the interests of airports we have issued invitations to the Airport Operators Association, BAA plc and the Joint Airports Committee of Local Authorities. We have in particular asked JACOLA to take the lead in assessing the contribution of regional airports. The International Air Transport Association, the International Air Carrier Association and the British Air Transport Association have been invited to represent airlines.

We have asked the Association of British Travel Agents, the British Tourist Authority and the Air Transport Users Committee to represent, respectively, the interests of the travel and tourism industries and of consumers of air services (passenger and cargo).

To ensure a thorough examination of the important environmental implications of airport development, we have extended invitations to a number of bodies and organisations. These are the Federation of Heathrow Anti-Noise Groups; the Gatwick Area Conservation Campaign, the North-West Essex and East Herts Preservation Association; and the Airfield Environment Federation. We have also invited the participation of the chairmen of the consultative committees at each of the airports in question.

The local management of the different airports have been asked to contribute to the work of the airport technical subgroup, and British Rail and London Regional Transport have been invited to join the subgroup which will consider surface access. Finally, the working group will involve officials from the CAA and from the trade and industry, employment, defence and agriculture departments, as well as from the Department of Transport and the Department of the Environment.

We are confident that the expertise of those we have invited will enable the group to engage fully with the many issues it will address. Inevitably, it has not been possible to offer places to all of those wishing to participate. We hope that many of those not included will be able to put views forward through the various representative organisations on the group. We also intend to initiate shortly a wider, written consultation, to ensure the group has access to the views of others WA 40 with an interest in the issues. The results of this consultation will be an important contribution to the group's work.
Once we have heard from those invited to join the group, arrangements can go forward for the first of the meetings. We expect this to take place early next year.

section.title: IRAQI INVASION of KUWAIT: COST OF UK RESPONSE

body.p: Lord Jenkins of Putney asked Her Majesty's Government:
What is the total cost to date of the United Kingdom's military involvement in responding to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Ministry of Defence (The Earl of Arran): The full operating costs to date of the United Kingdom's military involvement in responding to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is estimated to be some £480 million.

section.title: THE GULF: COST OF UK MILITARY PRESENCE

body.p: Lord Jenkins of Putney asked Her Majesty's Government:
What is the current weekly cost of this country's military presence in the Gulf and what would be the estimated cost if military conflict ensued.

The Earl of Arran: The current full operating cost of our forces in the Gulf, including the latest enhancements announced by the Secretary of State last week, is estimated to be £24 million per week. Costs, if military conflict occurs, are not estimable.
Lord Molloy asked Her Majesty's Government:
What legislation will be introduced following Lord Cullen's report into the Piper Alpha disaster, and when.

Lord Cavendish of Furness: The implementation of Recommendation 18 of Lord Cullen's report will require the introduction of legislation to make parts of the Mineral Workings (Offshore Installations) Act 1971, and of the Petroleum and Submarine Pipe-Lines Act 1975 and relevant statutory provisions of the Health and Safety at Work, etc. Act 1974. It is possible that implementation of other recommendations may also require the introduction of legislation. It is too soon to say when any of such legislation will be introduced.

section.title: EUROPEAN SOCIAL FUND: VOCATIONAL TRAINING GRANT APPLICATIONS

body.p: Lord McCluskey asked Her Majesty's Government:

Which of the applications received from voluntary sector organisations for funding under the European Social Fund Vocational Training
WA 41 Programme have been approved and when the funds payable in respect of approved applications are to be paid to the voluntary sector organisations concerned.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Department of Employment (Viscount Ullswater): The Department of Employment has received some 500 applications in 1990 from the voluntary sector (out of a total of 2,500 applications). These applications are now being processed and those from the voluntary sector are being given priority.
Decisions on the great bulk of the applications will be notified to the voluntary sector by the end of November 1990, and the majority of payments are expected to be made by next January.
Lord Moran asked Her Majesty's Government:
Whether they will ask the Salmon Advisory Committee to investigate and report on the recent decline in runs of sea trout in many Scottish and Welsh rivers.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Scottish Office (Lord Strathclyde): This problem is already being investigated by scientists of the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland and of the Welsh Region of the National Rivers Authority. The results will not be available for some time.

In view of those investigations and the already substantial programme of work which the Salmon Advisory Committee has to complete on Atlantic Salmon, we have no plans at present to ask the commit tee to consider sea trout.
Lord Macaulay of Bragar asked Her Majesty's Government:

Lord Strathclyde: The position is as follows:
(a) The Scottish Law Commission's report on Child Abduction confined its recommendations to Scotland, but recognised that the problems involved required a Great Britain approach, which is currently under consideration. WA 42
(b) The recommendations of the Scottish Law Commission's report on Legal Capacity and Responsibility of Minors and Pupils were accepted by the Government and were expressed in the Age of Legal Capacity (Scotland) Bill, introduced as a Private Member's Bill with Government support in the House of Commons in 1989. The Bill failed to obtain a Second Reading.
(c) The Government are giving favourable consideration to the Scottish Law Commission's report on Civil Liability—Contribution.
(d) The Government have carried out a public consultation on the recommendations in the report on Prescription and Limitation of Actions (Latent Damage and Other Related Issues). The responses received are now being analysed.
(e) The Government attach considerable importance to the commission's report on Succession. In view of the complexity of this subject, we do not expect to reach a final decision on all the report's recommendations until we have confirmed that the proposals enjoy the broad backing of interested parties. We shall be issuing a consultative paper shortly seeking comments on the commission's recommendations.

section.title: INVASIVE MALIGNANT MELANOMA: INCREASE IN INCIDENCE

body.p: Lord Cocks of Hartcliffe asked Her Majesty's Government:
Whether the Chief Medical Officer of Health has suggested any reasons for the increase in reported cases of invasive malignant melanoma from 1979 to 1989 respectively.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Department of Health (Baroness Hooper): Experts in this field generally believe that the increase in the incidence of melanoma in white populations is associated with increased exposure of untanned skin surfaces to solar ultraviolet radiation, but a precise causal mechanism has yet to be established.
Lord Mottistone asked Her Majesty's Government:

How many patients, and of them how many with schizophrenia, were discharged from mental illness hospitals in 1975, 1980, 1985 and 1987–88 indicating in each year: (a) numbers after first admission; and (b) numbers after a readmission with sub-headings, (i) in total; (ii) in less than one month; (iii) in less than three months; (iv) after six months or more but less than one year; (v) after one year or more but less than two years. (vi) after two years.

Baroness Hooper: The table shows the estimated number of discharges from the National Health Service hospitals (excluding the special hospitals) and units in the United Kingdom, and the number of those discharges with a diagnosis of schizophrenia. The
WA 43 figures include deaths and transfers to other hospitals, and do not relate to the number of patients, since the same individual may be readmitted and discharged more than once during a year. The figures for discharges are split between first admissions and readmissions to a psychiatric ward. Information is not collected centrally to enable a reply under the sub-headings specified.
Comparative figures for 1987–88 are not available.

body.p: Viscout Dilhorne asked Her Majesty's Government:
Whether they propose to publish a consultation paper on draft legislation to implement a commonhold scheme.

The Lord Chancellor (Lord Mackay of Clashfern): The Government are today publishing a document entitled Commonhold: A Consultation Paper (Cmnd. 1345). It includes a draft Bill. Comments are invited on this draft legislation and also on certain important policy issues, in particular whether provision should be made enabling the conversion to commonhold of residential long leasehold flats and other developments against the wishes of the landlord. The consultation paper is also available in a version without the draft Bill attached (Cmnd. 1346).
Lord Henderson of Brompton asked Her Majesty's Government:
What was the total income from fines in England and Wales in 1988–89 and 1989–90 respectively.

The Minister of State, Home Office (Earl Ferrers): The total income from fines and fees collected by magistrates' courts in England and Wales and paid into the Consolidated Fund was £188·8 million 1988–89 and £241·0 million in 1989–90. It is not possible to distinguish between fines and fees but fees account for only a very small proportion of the total.
Lord Henderson of Brompton asked Her Majesty's Government:
What was the average Home Office grant per place towards the cost of voluntary after-care hostels for offenders in 1988–89, 1989–90 and in the current financial year respectively.
Earl Ferrers: The average Home Office grant per place was £1,096 in 1988–89 and £1,206 in 1989–90. The provisional figure for 1990–91 is £1,336.
Lord Gainford asked Her Majesty's Government:
When they expect to publish a timetable for implementation of the Environmental Protection Act 1990.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Department of the Environment (Baroness Blatch): We have today placed in the Library copies of our target timetable for implementation of the Environmental Protection Act 1990. Part A of the timetable sets out for each subject area of the Act target dates for key tasks such as consultation on draft regulations, the laying of regulations and the ultimate target commencement dates. Part B lists the key tasks in chronological order.

The timetable covers implementation plans for the whole Act with the exception of the regulatory system under Part II—Waste on Land. This brings in a complete overhaul of our existing waste management systems and we are presently working on the timetable for this. A further announcement will be made on Part II as soon as possible.

The Environmental Protection Act is a landmark in environmental legislation. It brings with it valuable opportunities to enhance our domestic environment and contribute significantly to the development of international environmental policy. We must all be prepared to seize these opportunities so that future generations can benefit from a cleaner, healthier and greener world.
Lord Harris of Greenwich asked Her Majesty's Government:
Whether they have made representations to the Romanian Government concerning political dissidents still held in psychiatric institutions.
The Minister of State, Foreign and Commonwealth Office (The Earl of Caithness): We are investigating the matter with a view to taking it up with the Romanian authorities.
Lord Simon of Glaisdale asked Her Majesty's Government:
What provision they are making to monitor the cost of legal services after the coming into force of the provisions of the Courts and Legal Services Act 1990.

The Lord Chancellor (Lord Mackay of Clashfern): The provisions of the Courts and Legal Services Act 1990 are not aimed directly at achieving savings but rather at ensuring that the public has access to the best quality legal services for the particular needs of particular clients. The Government will of course continue to receive information about the cost of the provision of legal services under the Legal Aid Act.
Baroness David asked Her Majesty's Government:
What was the average cost of an attendance centre order in 1987–88, 1988–89, 1989–90 and the current financial year respectively.

The Minister of State, Home Office (Earl Ferrers): The average cost of an attendance centre order is estimated to have been £116 in 1987, £150 in 1988, and £156 in 1989. Figures for 1990 are not yet available.
Baroness David asked Her Majesty's Government:
What was the average annual cost of a place in a probation hostel in the most recent years for which figures are available.

Earl Ferrers: The most recently available information is that the average annual running cost of an occupied place in probation/bail and bail hostels to the Home Office and local authorities in 1988/89 was £8,797.
Baroness Ewart-Biggs asked Her Majesty's Government:

How many defendants have been monitored in each of the three electronic monitoring experiments; how many are currently being monitored; and how many have committed offences on bail or other violation of their bail conditions.

Earl Ferrers: Fifty defendants were electronically monitored in the course of three field trials. The trials ended earlier this year and no defendants have since been monitored. Twenty-nine defendants were arrested for bail violations or absconded in the course of the trials.

section.title:
AGRICULTURAL LAND FOR RENT:
LEGISLATIVE REVIEW

body.p: Lord Brougham and Vaux asked Her Majesty's Government:
What action they propose to take to improve the availability of agricultural land to rent.

The Minister of State, Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Baroness Trumpington): The Government believe that the tenanted sector is an important element in a healthy agricultural industry but it is clear that the current legislation is hindering the supply of land to rent. In discussions with the main interested organisations all have recognised the need for change. My right honourable friend the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food therefore intends to issue a consultative paper in the New Year with a view to securing a lasting and effective change without prejudice to the position of existing tenants.
Lord Brougham and Vaux asked Her Majesty's Government:

When the planned widening to four lanes of (i) the M.1 from the M.25 up to the M.18; (ii) the M.25, where it does not already have four lanes; and (iii) the M.6 between the junction with the M.1 and Manchester will start and how long this will take.

The Minister of State, Department of Transport (Lord Brabazon of Tara): Plans for widening these motorways have not yet reached a stage where firm dates can be given for the start and completion of the works involved. Widening can be done by a number of methods for which the time required for planning and building will vary, depending on the scale of civil engineering work involved and on whether more land needs to be acquired. The best choice of widening method will depend on local circumstances and detailed investigations to identify the most appropriate methods are still in progress or planned to start shortly.
Lord Simon of Glaisdale asked Her Majesty's Government:
What has been the annual income from parking meters since the inception of the scheme, and how much money has been spent each year on the provision of off-street parking over the same period.

Lord Brabazon of Tara: Information is not collected centrally which distinguishes either between revenue from on-street parking meters and off-street car parks, or between expenditure on the provision of off-street car parking as opposed to on-street parking. Figures available show that, in aggregate, local authority parking revenue currently amounts to over £300 million a year in England. Surplus on-street revenue can only be applied for further parking provision or for highways or public transport purposes.

section.title:
LONDON RESIDUARY BODY:
REAPPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS

body.p: Lord Brougham and Vaux asked Her Majesty's Government:
When the reappointments of the members of the London Residuary Body will be announced.

The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State, Department of the Environment (Baroness Blatch): The following have been reappointed to the London Residuary Body for the period 1st January 1991–31st March 1993, or until the dissolution of the body, whichever is sooner:

Members: Councillor Sir Peter Bowness, CBE, DL
J. Esling
W. Mackenzie, OBE
M. C. Roberts
J. Wolkind, CBE

The London Residuary Body has completed the bulk of its ex-GLC tasks and has already distributed £486 million in capital receipts and £184 million in revenue balances for the benefit of London's chargepayers.

The reappointments reflect the confidence of my right honourable friend the Secretary of State for the Environment in the board's ability to discharge the new tasks which the Residuary Body assumed on 1st April 1990 on the abolition of ILEA.

section.title:
PRIVATISATION OF CROWN SUPPLIERS'
VEHICLE HIRE BUSINESS AND THE INTER-
DEPARTMENTAL DESPATCH SERVICE

body.p: Lord Brougham and Vaux asked Her Majesty's Government:
When they expect to announce the outcome of the sale competition for the Crown Suppliers' vehicle hire business and the inter-departmental despatch service.

Baroness Blatch: Discussions are continuing on the sale of the Crown Suppliers' vehicle hire and maintenance business. An announcement will be made as soon as possible. There are no acceptable bids for the inter-departmental despatch service, which will, therefore, be retained in Government.

section.title:
LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PROMOTION OF
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT) REGULATIONS
1990

body.p: Lord Lyell asked Her Majesty's Government:
Whether they have received any representations about the Local Government (Promotion of Economic Development) Regulations 1990.

Baroness Blatch: The Association of District Councils and a number of individual councils have argued that it would be sufficient if local authorities which are not education authorities consulted their local education authority about the programmes of education and training which they provide for economic development purposes. We have accepted this, and the Department of the Environment is consulting the local authority associations on draft regulations to replace the current requirement to obtain the consent of the local education authority to those programmes with a requirement to consult the local education authority. The draft regulations also make it clear that the new economic development power is not intended to change the rules on the disposal of land at less then the best consideration reasonably obtainable.
Lord Norrie asked Her Majesty's Government:
How many dwellings each local authority has sold under the right to buy legislation, or voluntarily, in each year since 1979; and what percentage of the total local authority stock they represent.

Baroness Blatch: We have today placed in the Library two tables giving available information on local authority sales up to June 1990. Table 1 shows year by year information for each authority during the years 1979–80 to 1985–86. Table 2 shows year by year information for each authority since 1985–86 together with cumulative figures since April 1979 and the proportion of their stock sold since April 1979.
